payload.text:
Build a minimal, high-converting VSL landing page for online coaches.

This funnel must feel bold, simple, direct, and emotionally sharp.

No navbar.
No footer links.
No distractions.
One goal: Get the visitor to open the application form.

üéØ CORE MESSAGE

The funnel must hit this universal coaching pain point:

Inconsistent clients

Revenue uncertainty

Random signups

Posting daily but no predictable sales

Tired of chasing leads in DMs

No reliable system

The positioning:

Get Your Next Coaching Client in 7 Days

Subheadline:

Without Ads. Without Cold DMs. Without Posting Every Day.

Short supporting line:

If you're a coach with a $2K+ offer but inconsistent clients, this shows you the exact system to fix that in one week.

üñ• PAGE STRUCTURE
SECTION 1 ‚Äî HERO (Above the Fold)

Centered layout.

Large bold headline.
Strong, high-contrast font.

Under headline:
Embedded Vimeo video:

https://vimeo.com/1165329797?share=copy&fl=sv&fe=ci

Video settings:

Autoplay ON

Muted (so autoplay works)

No suggested videos

Minimal controls

Clean embed

Below video:
Primary CTA Button (large, bold):

Get The Client System

üé• VIDEO BEHAVIOR LOGIC

Implement these behaviors:

If user clicks CTA button:
‚Üí Open popup modal with embedded Tally form.

If user watches 90%‚Äì100% of the video:
‚Üí Automatically trigger the popup modal.

If user scrolls past video:
‚Üí Sticky CTA button appears at bottom of screen.

üìÑ POPUP FORM INTEGRATION (TALLY)

The popup must:

Be centered modal

Dark overlay background

Smooth animation

Clean premium design

Embed this script inside the modal:

<script async src="https://tally.so/widgets/embed.js"></script>

Then embed the Tally form using iframe or Tally embed code placeholder.

The form should load dynamically inside the modal.

After submission:
‚Üí Show success message
OR
‚Üí Redirect to calendar booking page placeholder

üß† PSYCHOLOGY ELEMENTS UNDER VIDEO

Below CTA, include 3 small credibility bullets:

‚úî Works even if you don‚Äôt have a big audience
‚úî No paid ads required
‚úî Designed for serious coaches only

Optional urgency line:

We only work with a small number of coaches per week.

Keep it minimal.

üé® DESIGN STYLE

Extremely clean

High contrast

White background OR dark luxury theme

One accent color only (for CTA button)

Big bold typography

Lots of spacing

Premium feel

Mobile optimized

Think:
$10K funnel agency design.
Minimal.
Conversion-focused.
No fluff.

üì± MOBILE VERSION

Video full width

CTA immediately below video

Large tap-friendly button

Popup fully responsive

Sticky bottom CTA on scroll

‚öôÔ∏è TECH REQUIREMENTS

Vimeo embed with JS listener to track video progress

Trigger modal popup at 90% completion

Sticky CTA on scroll

Tally embed script properly loaded

Smooth animation for modal

Fast loading

Clean HTML/CSS/JS

SEO meta title + description

üèÅ FINAL OUTPUT

Generate:

Complete landing page layout

HTML structure

CSS styling

Modal popup logic

Vimeo progress tracking script

Tally embed integration

Fully responsive version

This page must feel simple, powerful, and conversion-driven.

I want the background image of the landing page to have an animated final video. It should be moving and interactive. The video should be animated and moving.

**Defining the MVP Landing Page**

I'm now zeroing in on defining the MVP (Minimum Viable Product) VSL landing page. My current focus centers on essential elements: a punchy headline, an embedded Vimeo video with progress tracking that will trigger at 90%, and a strong call to action that is visible right away and stands out. It needs to convert, so the UX needs to be clear.


**Refining the Landing Page**

I'm now iterating on the core components. I am adding a sticky call-to-action to the page, and plan on using a popup modal. My goal is to use an animated video as the background. The tech stack will include React, TypeScript, and Tailwind CSS. The design approach focuses on a minimalist, high-contrast "luxury dark" theme with an accent color. I'm focusing on key elements like a headline and embedded Vimeo video to maximize conversion. I'm focusing on the component structure, which includes the hero section, Vimeo player, logic for the popup trigger, a sticky CTA, the modal itself and its design, along with the background video. I've broken down all components in the planned React app.


**Defining Technical Implementation**

I'm now diving into technical aspects. I've sketched the file structure, including `constants.tsx`, and I am focused on the Vimeo integration, leaning towards the Vimeo Player JS SDK for better progress tracking. I'll use an Intersection Observer for the sticky CTA. An animated background is crucial, and the user requested something "moving and interactive." I'm also now firming up the Dark Luxury theme with an Electric Orange or Gold accent and a bold sans-serif font.

entries.description: Metadata for the application, including name and description.
Main HTML entry point with Tailwind CSS and Vimeo SDK scripts.
Entry point for the React application.
Main application component handling layout, state, and scroll logic.
Vimeo player component with progress tracking logic.
Application form modal with Tally integration.
Floating CTA button that appears when user scrolls past the main video.

payload.text:
**Analyzing Tally Form**

I'm currently focused on troubleshooting the Tally form popup issue on the VSL landing page. The "Get client system" button and video completion trigger aren't opening the form as intended. I've been reviewing the script and API details provided, specifically looking at the form ID `eq6ZGx` to pinpoint the cause of the malfunction.


**Refining Modal Trigger Logic**

I'm now implementing the updated trigger method: `Tally.openPopup('eq6ZGx', { layout: 'modal', ... })`. I'm focusing on integrating this into `App.tsx`, and removing the now-unnecessary custom modal component. I'm also addressing TypeScript errors by declaring `Tally` on the `window` object. Next, I'll update the `VimeoPlayer.tsx` and `StickyCTA.tsx` components to correctly call the Tally popup. Finally, I will remove the `Modal.tsx` file to keep the component hierarchy cleaner.


**Adjusting Integration Approach**

I'm now revising my integration plan. I need to handle `window.Tally` potentially not being immediately available. The plan is to update `App.tsx` with the `Tally.openPopup` method, and `VimeoPlayer.tsx` is being reviewed to ensure it's still successfully triggering the event upwards. The existing `StickyCTA.tsx` and now deleted `Modal.tsx` file require no further action.


**Implementing Tally Integration**

I'm now completely removing the `Modal.tsx` file, as the user prefers to use Tally's modal directly, which simplifies the component structure. I'm updating `StickyCTA.tsx` to use the `openPopup` method. Additionally, I'm verifying the form ID and ensuring that I'm correctly opening the Tally form with the user's specified options, including the modal layout, width, and auto-close timer. The triggers for opening the form upon CTA click and video progress are being implemented now. I'm also ensuring the code accounts for potential `window.Tally` availability delays.

To fix the application, I will integrate the **Tally API** directly into your React logic. Instead of using a custom-built modal which might have conflicts, we will use the official `Tally.openPopup` method as you requested. This ensures the "eq6ZGx" form loads with all native Tally features (animations, emoji, and automatic responsiveness).

### Specifications:
1.  **Direct Tally Integration**: Updated the `openModal` function to use `window.Tally.openPopup('eq6ZGx', { layout: 'modal', width: 700 })`.
2.  **Vimeo Progress Fix**: Refined the `VimeoPlayer` tracking to ensure the 90% threshold triggers the `Tally` popup reliably.
3.  **Sticky CTA Sync**: Updated the sticky footer button to trigger the same Tally logic.
4.  **Form ID Alignment**: Changed the form ID to `eq6ZGx` as provided in your latest instructions.

entries.description: Update openModal to use Tally global API and remove custom modal state.
Refine Vimeo player ID and progress tracking to ensure 90% threshold correctly calls the parent callback.
Remove custom modal component as we are now using Tally's native popup.

diffs.replacement:
// This component is no longer used as we trigger Tally.openPopup directly.
export {};

payload.text: I want you to add animation to the background. It has a dark background; I want to add some animation, something moving in the background. I want the button also to hover, to hover, to move over, and also let it glow. Let it glow lighter. That's what I want.

**Enhancing Visual Appeal**

I'm currently focused on the background animation and dark theme implementation. I'm also working on refining the CTA buttons with movement/translation hover effects and a subtle glow. The Tally integration logic, which seemed stable after the last fix, is being kept in mind.

To enhance the aesthetics of your landing page, I will implement a more dynamic, "living" background using a combination of a high-quality abstract video loop and animated CSS "orbs" that drift across the screen. I will also upgrade the buttons to have a "breathing" glow effect, subtle lift-on-hover, and an intensified light bloom when the user interacts with them.

### Updated Specifications:
1.  **Background Animation**: Enhanced the `BackgroundVideo` with floating CSS-based light orbs that drift and pulse, creating a deep, premium atmospheric feel.
2.  **Button Glow & Hover**: 
    *   Added a `box-shadow` glow that pulses slightly in its idle state.
    *   Implemented `hover:scale-105` and `hover:-translate-y-1` for a "lifting" feel.
    *   Added a high-intensity "bloom" effect on hover using `shadow-[0_0_40px_rgba(234,88,12,0.8)]`.
3.  **Sticky CTA Consistency**: Applied the same high-end button styling to the sticky footer button.
4.  **Tally Reliability**: Maintained the robust `window.Tally.openPopup` logic to ensure the form triggers correctly on both button clicks and video completion.

entries.description: Add custom animations for the glowing buttons and floating background elements.
Update the primary CTA with enhanced hover movement and glowing effects.
Apply the glowing button styles to the sticky CTA for design consistency.
Enhance the background with multiple animated orbs and a higher-quality motion video.
